1.heading: French Class.
1.title: "Massacre" p. 37 in Agrippina
1.author: Claire Bretécher (London : Methuen, 1991).
notes: Summary: Agrippina gets a D-minus in French, and dramatizes her parents' probable reaction.

2.heading: French Class.
2.title: "Sounds Like Joey's Study Cards for French Class"
2.author: Cullum & Marshall.
notes: Summary: Some cards on the sidewalk have things like "Why didn't you do your homework" on one side, and things like "I caught diphtheria" and "The dog got it" on the other.

3.title: "The French Coagulation"
3.author: author, Carl Wessler and Gerry Boudreau ; illustrator, Luis Bermejo
notes: Contents page title: "Coagulation."

4.title: "French Comic Book" p. 16-19 in Fling Festival, v. 1, no. 1
4.author: [No author]
notes: Translates a "typical French comic book" 8 page story titled "Amours Camarouaises," by Didier Serdet, with caption summaries of each page.

5.title: "French Comic Books"
5.author: The Mosers
5.appears_in: p. 12 in Comic Book Marketplace, no. 21 (Jan./Feb. 1993).
notes: (Marketplace Mail)
Letter from homeschooling parents asking how to find French-language comics.

6.title: French Comics : clipping file.
6.author: [No author]
notes: 1 portfolio ; 25 x 38 cm.
Collected at Michigan State University in the Russel B. Nye Popular Culture Collection's Popular Culture Vertical File (PCVF).

7.heading: French Comics and Spoken Language.
7.title: Kébra, le Rat Braqué : French Comics and Spoken language
7.author: Alan Farrell.
notes: 12 leaves ; 28 cm.
Includes bibliographical references.
Paper from second annual International Comics and Animation Festival, Washington, D.C., Sept. 26-29, 1996, but not listed in program book.
Discusses work of French creators Jano and Tramber.

9.heading: French Comics Artists--Interviews.
9.title: Itinéraires dans l'Univers de la Bande Dessinée
9.author: Michel-Edouard Leclerc ; avec Chantal-Marie Wahl ; reportage photographique de Jean Bibart et Philippe Germanaz.
notes: Includes bibliographical references (p. 294-295).
Book about French comics done through interviews with 52 artists.

10.heading: French Comics Artists--Miscellanea.
10.title: "Above Average American"
10.author: by John Workman
10.appears_in: p. 4 in Heavy Metal, v. 6, no. 8 (Nov. 1982).
notes: Editorial compares French and American comics artists.

11.heading: French Comics Colorists--Articles About.
11.title: "Coloriage, Picturalité et Gros Sous"
11.author: par Sylvain Bouyer
11.appears_in: p. 35-39 in Les Cahiers de la Bande Dessinée, no. 60 (Nov./Dec. 1984).
notes: Article on the history of color in and coloring of comics, with a chart showing the first known work of 38 French colorists.

12.heading: French Comics Colorists--Articles About.
12.title: "Profession: Coloriste"
12.author: Sylvain Bouyer
12.appears_in: p. 40-43, 57 in Les Cahiers de la Bande Dessinée, no. 60 (Nov./Dec. 1984).
notes: Responses by ten colorists to a questionnaire about their profession: Isabelle Beaumenay-Joannet, Pascale Bénureau (1958-), Christine Couturier (1959-), Anne Delobel (1949-), Danielle Dubos (1940-), Didier Eberoni (1958-), Raymond Fernandez (1953-), Marianne Rousseau (1956-), Jean Solé (1948-), and Evelyne Tran-Lê (1940-).

14.heading: French Comics Publishers--Articles About.
14.title: "Comment Faire Publier Votre BD : Vade-mecum du Dessinateur Débutant"
14.author: Serge Mayence ; enquête, Nathalie Coucke
14.appears_in: p. 39-43 in Les Cahiers de la Bande Dessinée, no. 64 (July/Aug. 1985).
notes: (Enquête)

The same comics art, borrowed from a promising art student, was offered to, and the same questions asked of, the major Franco-Belgian comics publishers, resulting in suggestions for aspiring comics authors and sample rejection letters.

15.heading: French Comics Publishers--Articles About.
15.title: "La Dynastie des Offenstadt"
15.author: par George Fronval
notes: Begins the history of a French publishing enterprise responsible for many pre-World War II comics.
To be continued.

16.heading: French Comics Publishers--Articles About.
16.title: "L'Irrésistible Ascension de l'Édition Indépendante"
16.author: Jean-Philippe Martin
16.appears_in: p. 22-31 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 5 (Jan. 2000).
notes: (Dossier : Un Bilan des Années 90).

Begins: "Présents pour la première fois sur un même stand au Salon du Livre de Paris in 1999, une vingtaine de petits éditeurs francophones, comptant parmi les plus actifs comme Amok, Cornélius, Ego comme X, Fréon et bien sûr l'Association, venaient prouver du haut de leurs 500 ouvrages publiés en l'espace de 10 ans, qu'au-delà des plus folles espérances, un véritable renouveau de la bande dessinée de création avait trouvé à s'incarner. Un dossier tirant le bilan des années 1990 exigeait que l'on revînt sur la montée en puissance de ce que l'on désigne souvent comme 'l'édition indépendante' (qu'il serait peut-être plus juste d'appeler, tout simplement, 'les petits éditeurs').

English summary (from p. 150): "The Irresistible Ascension of the Independent Publishers. Amok, the Association, La Cinquième couche, Cornélius, Ego comme X, Fréon, the Requins marteau, 6 Pieds sous Terre: these are some of the main independent publishers that have emerged during the last decade. Small organizations, often founded and run by creators, they maintain an uncompromising conception of creation and produce objects that are distinct from the traditional album. Their rise has been steady, as Jean-Philippe Martin shows. He predicts they will influence the future of comics in general."

17.heading: French Comics Publishers--Books About.
17.title: Les Éditeurs de Bande Dessinée

notes: (Profession)
On cover: L'Association, Casterman, Cornélius, Dargaud, Delcourt, Dupuis, Frémok, Glénat, Les Humanoïdes Associës, Kana, Soleil.
